{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3476247,"name":"William Duong","username":"wduong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ad7895/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T03:20:24.906Z","cooked":"
REV Robotics

Linear Actuator - 12in Stroke

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 220

Would it be possible to cut down the middle 2x2 tube to make the linear actuator shorter? it looks like its just a piece of extrusion so I was thinking it might be viable.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T03:20:24.906Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":78,"reads":251,"readers_count":250,"score":440.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-21-2735/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Linear Actuator - 12in Stroke - REV Robotics","clicks":29}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3476596,"name":"Rocky","username":"Rocky_S","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rocky_s/{size}/220194_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T13:41:12.238Z","cooked":"

You mean the middle 1x1?

It seems to me the 1x1 only extends out the “black box” a tiny bit when fully extracted, and I think you want it to stick out a bit so you can actually mount something to the end of the 1x1

I think you can cut it just a little bit shorter as long as it still extends out the 1x1 when fully retracted, but I don’t think cutting the 1x1 is good idea

If you want less stroke just program it to extend out shorter

i was talking about the outside, black, 2x2

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T14:15:47.922Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":45.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":58611,"username":"Rocky_S","name":"Rocky","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rocky_s/{size}/220194_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476644,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T14:23:39.731Z","cooked":"

Looks like there’s nothing stopping you from cutting the actuator down. There are two pieces that span the length of the actuator, the outer black 2"x2" housing, and the lead screw. As long as you cut the leadscrew down from the plain end, leaving the machined end (red circle) intact, you should be fine. I would bevel the cut end of the screw and clean it thoroughly so that there are no burrs that damage the lead nut when you put it on.

image1059×578 83.2 KB

thank you for your comments. I’m not sure what the lead screw actually looks like but would it be viable to order a lead screw from mc master carr that is already the correct length and with the correct thread? Or is there something special about the REV lead screw?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:19:56.942Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":138,"readers_count":137,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23148,"username":"kitare102","name":"Eric Bergquist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476712,"name":"burde1jb","username":"burde1jb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/burde1jb/{size}/270229_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:24:42.260Z","cooked":"

We picked up a couple of these before the season just to see how they work. The black case is just extrusion with an end caps placed during the build on either side. So you could cut down the 2 x 2, but then you would not get the full 12" extension.

For the lead screw - the diameter and pitch are listed on the product description website you linked so I imagine you could go shopping for a McMaster-Carr equivalent. Good luck!

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:24:42.260Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"burde1jb","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17898,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Team 4327"},"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/6","custom_user_title":"FRC Team 4327","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476713,"name":"Arjun Ohri","username":"arjunorsmth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:24:42.774Z","cooked":"

Sorry if this is a stupid question, but can you reasonably lift a robot with a geared up REV linear actuator? I’m trying to find small mechanisms for linear motion that we can use to replicate a “donut climb” with the deep cage.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:24:42.774Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"Arjun Ohri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66645,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead"},"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/7","custom_user_title":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476719,"name":"William Duong","username":"wduong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ad7895/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:26:49.365Z","cooked":"

that is what our team is thinking. What is really helpful with the lead screw is that the power required to hold the robot up using the linear actuator is not as much we think using the donut climb.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:26:49.365Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":106,"readers_count":105,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":66645,"username":"arjunorsmth","name":"Arjun Ohri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476722,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:28:09.974Z","cooked":"

No problem! I would definitely recommend cutting down the existing Rev leadscrew, as it has custom geometry on the “motor” end to screw into the adapter for the hex input. You will not find anything on McMaster with that specific feature.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:28:09.974Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":20.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"Eric Bergquist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":70768,"username":"wduong","name":"William Duong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ad7895/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23148,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/9","custom_user_title":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476725,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:30:19.419Z","cooked":"

Good question! I would recommend using this link to try and calculate the reduction that you would need: ReCalc . (Edit: this calculator doesn’t really have the right inputs for leadscrews. I’m not sure any of the ReCalc calculators do, though I’d love for someone to correct me. (Edit the Second: Actually, you can just put 12mm/3.14159 into the “spool diameter”, as that diameter spool would move something 12mm per revolution just like the leadscrew does)

If left at the full 12", I would worry about whether the 1"x1" extension shaft is supported well enough to handle the full robot weight. But, if you only have a few inches of stick out from the end of the black body of the actuator, that will be much better supported.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:38:32.290Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":50.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"Eric Bergquist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/linear","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66645,"username":"arjunorsmth","name":"Arjun Ohri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23148,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/10","custom_user_title":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476734,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:34:41.445Z","cooked":"

As a general counterpoint here:

The rev leadscrew is a very aggressively pitched screw, one turn is 12mm and the product page says it is backdrivable. It does have a nice sensor built in though (and maybe you need to push something and pull…)

A climber in a box has better suited features for climbs that are “grab and reduce length” and are easier to modify in length.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:43:16.362Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":43.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/11","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476738,"name":"William Duong","username":"wduong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ad7895/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:36:12.578Z","cooked":"

how would one push down using a climber in the box? my understanding of telescoping sliders is that springs are used to pull the climber up and rope is used to pull the top stage down.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T15:36:12.578Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3476741,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T15:38:33.774Z","cooked":"

Correct, that spring force is what makes it extend.

Could you share a simple sketch of what you are trying to accomplish? I think I get what you are trying to do, but I don’t want to give you the wrong info.

Nothing says the gearing you put behind the leadscrew has to also be backdriveable. A high-reduction MAXPlanetary would probably lock that up.

Maybe they could sell an “upgrade” kit (more like side-grade) that changes the high-pitch leadscrew for a low-pitch one that is not backdriveable. Not sure if the rest of the components on the linear actuator would be appropriate for that, forces-wise. Basically, turn the product into something suitable for climbing.

Do you think it would be easier at that point to use a rack and pinion system? I think this mechanism can be very similar to climbers from 2019, and I’ve heard that rack and pinion systems were used back then(also side question: what were some of the other systems used to climb on hab 3 in 2019? I can’t find a ton of CAD or discussion around it.)

Rack and pinion is another way to get linear motion, but I think the entire reason you would use this actuator is that the packaging is convenient and you don’t have to manufacture many custom components. It’s pretty easy to fit this inside the cage so that it is pushing down directly on the center of the bottom plate. Otherwise, you would need to have the cantilever on the moving part of the actuator, which would cause torques that the Rev actuator probably won’t handle very well. You could imagine a big pneumatic cylinder doing the same operation.

In the below picture, the colors represent:

  • Red: Cage
  • Blue: Cut down actuator
  • Green: Maxplanetary with high reduction
  • Yellow: Strong attachment to the structure of the robot
  • Purple: Some sort of cone to align in the hole on the bottom plate

image301×625 7.39 KB

yes this is what we were imagining. is this modeled to scale? our only concern was getting the center of mass as close as possible to the purple cone vertically and horizontally. my understanding is that the cog should be over or under the purple cone is that right?

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-01-09T18:13:14.929Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":56,"readers_count":55,"score":16.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":480354,"topic_slug":"modifying-rev-linear-actuator","display_username":"William Duong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23148,"username":"kitare102","name":"Eric Bergquist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70768,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/modifying-rev-linear-actuator/480354/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3477009,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-09T18:34:48.444Z","cooked":"

Yes, everything is to scale including the shortened actuator. Ideally the CoG should be right above the cone, both because the robot will tip less and you will put less torque on the actuator shaft. I suspect as long as your mounting structure has the standard 0.5" hole pitch, that should be good enough to fine-tune exactly where the actuator is relative to the robot CoG.

However, since the robot CoG will be above the cone, you wil be unstable and may need another actuator or catch to prevent the robot tipping out of the cage. Alternately, position the CoG such that you tip in a direction that will not tip you out of the cage.
